segments.text: robotics program came out of our productivity program.
The industrial engineering department is now involved in an Air Force effort to set up an artificial intelligence program.
And a lot of the advanced manufacturing system work that is currently being done by Dr. Don Phillips and others in industrial engineering
had its roots in the Park Community.
And so, although it does not exist as such now, it laid the foundation for some activities that are currently going on.
And incidentally, here again, the only reason that that thing succeeded was that Mr. Benson and Mr. Whitmore gave me a chunk of T's money with which to promote it.
And that's the only thing we did.
And if I can tell you just a quick story about that time.
Dr. Ray Goforth, who at that time was in industrial engineering, but now is in industrial engineering, is in mechanical engineering.
And is a very competent guy.
One summer, using T's money,

we pursued this problem of why weren't numerically controlled machines showing up, particularly in what we call the mom-and-pop machine shops, the little job shops that, again, dot the back alleys of Houston and Dallas and other large cities.
And don't misunderstand, they're not always just real small operations.
Some of those things are really small.
And so with T's money, we did a study of barriers to the utilization of numerically controlled machines in small shops.
It turned out to have been a mere classic.
And gave us credibility that led to research activities, research sponsorships.
And this is, again, you see, the thing that you have to do.
You can't take an outfit that has no track record in a given area and go to a sponsor and say, here, give me some money to do some work in that area.
He's going to say, well, what the hell have you done?
And quite improperly so.
And if you say, well, nothing, but if you give us some money, we're going to do something great.
That ain't going to get it.

And so we, the money that we got from the National Science Foundation came out of a, really came out of that little study that Ray Goforth did for us back in the summer of 77, I think, or 76, I can't remember.
And it led to an exchange that I had with a guy from the National Science Foundation because they had a productivity program at that time.
And the interesting thing that came out of our study was that the reason people weren't using these advanced manufacturing systems was because they were afraid of them.
They didn't understand.
They didn't understand what these devices could do for them, and they were afraid of what they might do to them.
And Ray's work that summer, and he had a couple of students working on it, I thought was magnificent.
And it brought that forth very clearly.
As it so happened, I went to a meeting sponsored by the National Science Foundation dealing with productivity matters, and they got into this very issue.
Their view, traditional Bank of the Potomac's myopia, was that it all rested on money.
If these people just had money, they would go buy these machines and use them and so forth.
But hell, it was obvious that
that the people in Houston, I mean, most of them tied to the petrochemical industry, making machine parts for them, they were laughing all the way at the bank.
I mean, money was anything but a problem.

And so, as a matter of fact, in this public meeting up in Rochester, New York, I got into another heated discussion with this guy from the National Science Center, who was a friend, was and is a friend.
So I told him, we've got data to dispute that.
And so he said, I want to see that.
And so he did see it, and that led to a lot of things.
We eventually got involved in the Air Force's ICAM program, the Integrated Manufacturing Program, largely because they were concerned about technology transfer.
Because of this little rigging study that we had done, we're sort of nationally recognized experts on technology transfer.
But it's just an indication, again, of the power of just a little bit of tea's winning.
And again, if it hadn't been there, we wouldn't have done it.
Let's go back to the flight land in 1964.
Oh, okay.
Before we move on farther.
Yeah, okay, back to the 60s then.
Well, of course I had naturally, when I came here in 64, having been involved in hypersonic and reentry research associated with the space program at that time,
And I don't think, you know, at that time we couldn't foresee that as soon as the Apollo program had been successful that everything was going to go downhill.
We just, you know, we thought that investing in space-type research was a heck of a good thing to do.
So I was obviously interested in promoting that when I came down here.
And I was primarily an experimentalist.
I hadn't done a lot of theoretical work.
It was mostly wind tone work and making those experiments.
Of course, we didn't have a hypersonic facility here.
And so it seemed as though that the most inexpensive facility that we could develop was a shock tube, which is a device that will create hypersonic flows for very, very short periods of time.
And basically, you have this large tube, and you create a very high pressure shock wave that rushes down the tube and pulls the air
behind it, with it, at very high speeds.
And so you can do some good... Back in those days, of course, the work that needed to be done was very, very basic work.
Because aerodynamics was in a completely new realm.
Normally, of course, air is nitrogen and oxygen.
N2 and O2, both diatomic molecules, principally.
Well, those molecules, in addition to bouncing off one another like billiard balls, the individual atoms in the molecule vibrate.
There is an intermolecular bond based on largely the electronic attraction that holds them together.
But when you talk about a reentry theory,
coming, whistling back into the atmosphere at very, very high speeds.
It has a shockwave event.
There's a temperature jump across that shockwave.
There's a temperature jump across any shockwave, even though it might be, you know, if you have a Mach 2 fighter, or a Concorde, you know, anything.
But when you talk about Mach 2 or Mach 20,
The temperature joke is so great that it causes those molecules, those atoms, to cause the molecules to dissociate.
And so you have a chemical reaction.
The M2 becomes 2N.
The same thing for oxygen.
So this air, or this gas behind this shock wave, is no longer air.
It's some weird new gas.
And the fact that that structure has changed
makes it, made it very difficult to predict the lift and drag of things like the Mercury capsule.
If you recall the early Mercury flights, some of them, there was one, who flew that?
I can't remember.
I think it was the third flight.
The guy landed miles from the touchdown point.
And the principal reason there was
Of course, he was flying at somewhat the wrong angle of attack coming back in.
But nonetheless, our inability to predict lift and drag was very great.

largely because we just didn't understand this strange new and then the ionization blackout, you know, where even though the temperatures were so high that the electrons would peel off of these atoms and create this sheath of ions behind it, and the radio wave wouldn't penetrate it.
So we had that ionization blackout period going on.
And so all of that stuff at that time was, God, that was just, that was way out stuff.
And so shock tubes could create shock waves strong enough to cause those chemical reactions.
And so we could study them.
And so, again, good old teams and good old Harry Whitmore gave me, I can't remember, I think it was $40,000 or $50,000, I think, to build a shock tube.
And we did.
And again, that was the foundation for some research work, and which, again, simply would not have happened had we not gotten that money for TEEs.
Well, so the shock tube lab, and we had a building given to us out at the annex.
It wasn't much of a building,
but it worked out extremely well.
And then, too, we had another strange event happen.
At about 65 or 66, some students came to me and said, well, the traditional areas of activity or specialization within

of aerospace engineering are aerodynamics, which has to do with the flow of air about these mines, structures, making them strong enough but light enough that they'll fly, and propulsion, which deals with engines and power plants, and that sort of thing.
But the fourth area is flight mechanics, which deals with the entire vehicle.
It deals with stability and control and performance
maneuverability and that sort of thing.
And so, some students came to me and said, you know, they were interested in more inflective things.
Wasn't there anything we could do to get active in that area?
Well, here we were with a beautiful facility.
The old Bryan Air Force Base
parallel 7,500 foot runways.
And at that time, we had horses running over those runways.
To me, being one who has been hooked on airplanes for many, many years, I think the saddest thing that one can see is an abandoned airplane, an airplane that
there's a relic that's just uncared for sitting on the corner of an airport or in a hangar and just falling.
And you think that at one time it must have been a beautiful sight in flight.
And there it sits, rusting and deteriorating.
The second saddest thing
I think it's an abandoned airport.
Well, you could imagine that all the times there were great and wonderful things that happened in the past.
People learning to fly.
Now it's just a cow pasture, or in that case, a horse pasture.
And they had hangers out there that were just unused.
And so,
I thought, well, gosh, maybe we could do something with that facility.
Now, there was another thought that entered my mind at that time, and that was that we had gotten the wind tunnel, the big wind tunnel, back in operation, and we were working there.
And it occurred to me that if we could have a sweat lab, that that would give us a very powerful combination.
we could not only do wind tunnel tests, but we could take the results of those tests and flight test them.
Put them actually on an airplane, you see.
And the number of institutions, universities that had that capability were very, very limited.
Count them easily on a finger and one hand.
And so I thought,
It just might lead to something good.
Well, here again, thank God for Aggie students and their unbelievable enthusiasm.
And thank God for Key's money.
Because, again, I went to Harry Whitmore and laid the idea before him.
And I have to tell you, dear,
I don't think I have ever gone to Harry Woodward and said, I need this.
And that's just unbelievable.
I mean, that's incredible.
But in any event, he said, yeah, let's pursue that.
And so he gave me a little bit of money with which I could hire some students.

And so the first thing they did was to, and then Mr. Benson went to that for us and got the animal science people to move their damn fences off the runways so we could have access to some of the runways.
And that was not easy to do.
Excuse me?
Were the runways still in good shape?
Oh, yeah.
Uh-huh.
Yeah.
They just had fences across them.
But as you know, the Ags run this institution, and I guess always will, even though...
But it was not...
It required the clout that Mr. Benson had in order to get that airport made back into an airport.
Well, we got that done, and my students had surveyed the runways, and some of the older runways were not in very good shape, but TTI was using them, so that was okay.
But the two new runways that had been built for jet use in the very late 50s, I think, when the Air Force Base was still active, they were in great shape.
But we were, you know, they looked at the landing lights and runway lights, whether or not they could be used.
We might use them at night.
The answer there was no.
They'd all be just in gasoline storage facilities, and they would pretty much deteriorate.
Things like that.
And we had, and Harry got us the hangar out there that is currently the flight lab hangar.
And, of course, it looked like it was about to fall down, and so we had to have some structural reinforcement of that hangar and so forth.
Well, if you're going to have a flight test facility, it helps to have an airplane.
And so I had been a pretty successful scrounger of surplus property.

And so here was where the Research Foundation came in, and Mr. A.D. Rickett, who is currently the Vice President of the Research Foundation, but at that time he was property manager of the Research Foundation, and among other things, handled all the surplus property.
Well, this got to be a joke, and Rick and I are now very close friends, and we still talk about those days,
he used to get these lists of surplus property.
And we would go through those lists, and I got some stuff for the shock tube, and I got some things for the wind tunnel, and it turned out there was occasionally an airplane that would show up.
Well, most of the time they were large airplanes, and not particularly well suited to
to research with.
And that triggers a whole lot of memories.
But also keep in mind, again, this was mid and late 60s.
And we were trying to, the government was trying to help the Vietnamese.
We had, we were tracking two airplanes pretty closely.
And within, of course, a space of two weeks, these were surplus airplanes.
Within the course of two weeks, we lost both of them because they had decided that they were going to take anything that would fly and pretty much give it to the Vietnamese.
And so here we were with a flight lab and some eager students and no airplanes.
Well, I had heard from Mr. Bruce, who incidentally deserves an awful lot of credit for all of this, because Joe, and he had the beginnings of the research and instrument shop on the way at that time.
And, of course, he's, he's, Joe Bruce is an absolute genius when it comes to the electromechanical department.
He is absolutely a genius, and doesn't get the credit that he deserves, I think, for what he has contributed to TEAS and to the College of Engineering.
But I knew from Joe that Grumman Aircraft had given us, had given Texas A&M the number one and number two
rum and egg cats.
These were airplanes that were built to be crop dusters.
In other words, they were designed from the ground up as crop dusters.
They were not converted to that use.
And back in the early days before I came here, as a matter of fact it was still underway when I came here, in the plant sciences department there was a crop dusting research program.
They had the
was that I think it was the number two aircraft that they were flying.
They had different kinds of spray apparatus and so forth on them.
But the other airplane, the number one airplane, was not flying.
And so, well, if you're going to have an airplane, you better take a look at that thing.

I went out, and again, I had talked with Mr. Whitmore about this, and I said, you know, it may be that we'll have to rebuild that just in order to get something in the air again to, you know, how the hell could you go to a potential sponsor and propose research work if you don't even have an airplane with which to do it?
And so I'd
I'll never forget the day we went out there and Mr. Bruce got his keys and we went over to a warehouse there at the annex.
And he opened this door and there was this dark, dust-filled room laden with junk.
And there in the back of the room, with wings off, no engine,
was the fuselage of the ANCAT.
The wings were stacked up against the wall.
And I looked at my students and there was sort of a reenactment of the deal with the wind tunnel model.
And I said, folks, if we're going to have a flight lab, that's going to be our first research aircraft.
Well, there was a giant cloud of dust
And in about four or five months, I flew that aircraft that had been rebuilt.
A new engine put in it.
The hopper where the material to be sprayed had been taken out.
And Mr. Bruce had put a second cockpit in there.
Of course, an open cockpit by plane.
And we had, I had acquired some surplus research electronic gear, surplus electronic gear to put in there.
And we converted that old ag cat into a researcher.
And here again, it was all done with tees money.
And then we acquired the PA-18 from the Border Patrol out of Marfa.
And this is a Piper Cub.
It's a Super Cub, so-called, with a 150-horse engine.
And so we started with those two airplanes.
And so we had our airport.
We had the hangar.
We had two research airplanes.
And we had also had, if you visit the flight lab today, you'll see offices built along one side and in the back there.
None of that was there.
That was, again, all done with T's money.
And that was the beginning of the flight lab.
And again,
without tease, it just, it simply would not have happened.
It simply wouldn't have happened.
So... What year was that?
Do you remember?
I'm sorry?
Do you remember the year?
Oh, Lord, honey.
Late 60s?
We never had an official dedication.
I suppose we should have.
I think the flight lab
as I recall, was pretty well in operation by 67.
We had been doing a few little things prior to that.
As a matter of fact, I owned an airplane at that time, and we did a little research with it.
But we got the AGCAT going, I think, in the spring of 67.
And the PA-18 came along very, very shortly thereafter.
And so pretty much by the fall of 67, as I recall, we were pretty well in operation.
Now, how did, in 72,
became associate dean of engineering and director of the Center for Urban Programs.
What was the Center for Urban Programs?
Well, it was a strange place for an engineer to be, I'll tell you.
In late 71, after I'd come back from Maryland, and in that summer and fall of 71, and really the spring of 72,
That was the period of time when I was trying to find Mr. Benson, pursuing Mr. Benson's directive to seek out some new research areas.
In the midst of all that, well, again, you have to understand the mood at the time.
We were deep in the midst of what I call the age of relevance.
Everything that you did had to be relevant.
You had to serve mankind in a very direct way.
Our students, incidentally, respected that viewpoint.
There was no joy of learning.
There was no desire to learn anything, just for the fun of learning it.
It had to be relevant to something.
It had to be directly applicable.
And the engineering students of that day, they wanted to know just what they needed to know to be successful.
No more, no less, but just what they needed.
You still see some tinges of that today, but it's much diminished than what it was.
Well, the same thing applied to research.
And one heard that during those days, you know, if we can put a man on the moon, surely to God we can do blah, blah, blah.
And at that point, in that day and age, the problems of the urban areas had come to the fore.

a lot of that came out of the unrest of the late 60s and of course the cities were the focus of that unrest and although the unrest had its roots in other things people saw a declining quality of life in the cities and of course in recent years I guess we've seen
Demographically, we've seen the movement of people out in the cities and in smaller towns and rural areas and so on.
But there was great concern at that time for trying to help the cities.
And there was money, federal money, available.
The National Science Foundation at that time had developed what they called the RAN program, R-A-N-N. And that stood for Research Applied to the Nation's Needs.
And it was an interesting program.
And one part of it focused on urban problems.

And that, you know, that was sort of unheard of for the National Science Foundation, whose province had always been far out of physics, you know, atomic physics, nuclear physics, and some of the far reaches of chemistry and biology and so forth.
And now to get involved in an applied research program focused on the cities.
Well, they had some money.
And, uh, but in any event, to come back to Texas A&M, uh, uh, I was, uh, as I say, in this, uh, activity that Mr. Benson had directed before.
Uh, still working on the harry bar up front.
We had started some stuff in the advanced transportation area.
And, uh, and the productivity thing was just really beginning to, uh, to take with the,
And Lord, I can't think of his name.
The guy who was the city manager of the city of Dallas for many years.
He was then, at that time, he was an assistant city manager.
He was an incredible man.
I can't remember his name.
And, of course, by that time, Mr. Rutter had passed away, and Dr. Williams was president.
And so this gentleman, almost had his name there, but that's about it.
This gentleman from the city of Dallas, I can't remember whether he came down or whether he wrote a letter.
It seems like he wrote a letter.
to Dr. Williams, saying that he thought that Texas A&M ought to mount an effort to help the citizens of the state of Texas.
And so Dr. Williams then asked Mr. Benson, and I'm sure the reason that he did that was because of Tease.
Because, you see,
And this is, again, something we haven't touched on, but again, it's something I'm sure you've heard by now.
One of the great advantages that TEAS has is its ability to hang on to some of the indirect cost money that has that issue been explained to you.
And other engineering experiment stations, incidentally, don't have.
So it's an enormously powerful tool because, of course, it is the source of the money, coupled with the money that they get from the state.
It is the source of the money with which to do all these great things that I've been describing to you.
And so TEAS has been called upon by the university to start a lot of things.
you know, the cyclotron, the food protein center, the computer system, all started from peas and it was because they had money.
They were the only damn ones on the campus that did, pretty much.
All the ags happened when they spent it on ag things, you see.
But a different, different sack of snakes.
I mean, a lot of people will say,
Texas Agricultural Experiment Station, Texas Engineering Experiment Station.
Ah, about the same name.
It must be about the same.
Wrong.
It was different as night and day.
I wish to help Perry Atkinson could understand that.
And that's an editorial comment, obviously.
But the ag folks don't understand it.
And so Dr. Williams then asked Mr. Benson to pursue this initiative.
in the urban area.

And of course, Mr. Benson at that time had this gift by the name of Thomas that was supposed to be seeking out new research things for T's to do, and so he called me into his office and said, would you take a look at this?
And so that was the beginning of the Center for Urban Programs.
And so the first thing I did, of course not knowing anything,

about urban problems which i guess later on we saw that as kind of a blessing because i had no preconceived notions about what could be done or what couldn't be done but the first thing i did was to take some t's money and jump in my airplane and take a little tour around the state and talk with city officials
and sound them out on this whole thing.
And generally positive reaction.
Some were very cautious.
Some gave us some advice that was absolutely invaluable in the later functions of the Center for Academic Programs.
Again, I could go to those people and say, I have some money to spend.
Well, I came back after that jaunt and told Mr. Benson that I thought it was a viable thing, that I thought we would be relatively well received in the cities.
we had some hurdles to surmount.
And that I was relatively sure that with a properly constructed program that we could draw federal support.
And so Mr. Benson went back to Dr. Williams and told him that he thought we had the makings of a

the program here and he thought an organization ought to be established to pursue this and dr williams said fine mr chairman whom do you want on your committee so he named benson the chairman of the oversight committee and so then mr benson called together a group of five as i recall deans other deans and
But these, of course, were the deans of colleges that we thought we would draw on from, you know, to support that urban program.
So it included liberal arts, and it seems like the ag folks were there.
Yeah, Dr. Kunkel was there, and architecture, geosciences was there.
And I think, yeah, Frank Cuban, who was the dean of education, was there.
And so they formed a kind of an oversight group.
And so rather quickly then, the other things that I had been pursuing for Mr. Benson sort of went into the background.
And so we focused our efforts on these.
In the 50s, 40s and 50s, there had been a lot of research done on industrialization of cities and surveys and that type of thing.
Had this been going on, and did you then pick these things up and take them on, or did you start totally from scratch?
No, dearly.
Well, keep in mind, we had at that point, we had the Industrial Economics Research Division here run by Jim Bradley.
That was still doing those?
Oh yes, right.
And as a matter of fact, it was absorbed into this center when it was established in 78.
But not into the urban center?
No.
It functioned separately and it dealt with economic development.
No, the focus of the Center for Urban Programs was to help cities deliver services more efficiently.
And to manage more efficiently.
So we developed old continuing education programs for city managers and other subsystem managers.
For example, it would be of no surprise to you if I told you that we mounted a continuing education program for airport managers, which was quite successful for its brief tenure.
We embarked on a management assistance program, and, well, we had a lot of things underway.
And here again, at this point, I have to throw some more accolades at this pension.
When you start a program from scratch like that,
Here again, without any proven expertise to work in the area, you have to have money to develop some credibility.
And of course, I knew that I was to bring money as fast as I could.
I mean, we didn't want to be on the dole forever.
be using, be dependent on Pease money, uh, thought infinitely.
And, uh, so I well remember we were, uh, see that began in 72, I guess this, uh, this incident occurred like in 74 or 5.
We had had one or two small grants, uh,
to do urban work, but I was plainly concerned that this thing wasn't developing as fast as I thought it should.
And so I guess on one day when I was a bit down, I went to see Mr. Batson and I said, Skipper, I'm just not sure what this thing is for.
He listened to my lament and he said, Dick, you are too worried about bringing money home.
He said, you worry about building a quality program.
And if you do that, the money will come.
Let me worry about the money.
you just concentrate on building a quality building.
Well, darling, that's the way it ought to be done.
Again, to be somewhat critical of our current tease, leadership does not understand that the way Mr. Benson understood it.
So what I'm saying to you is that the power, the strength,

The sort of grudging respect that TEAS currently enjoys in the Texas A&M community, and I think in other parts of the state and the nation, is due largely to the preferences of you about how to build quality programs.
You don't build a quality program by throwing money at it for a year.
His view was that if I had a self-supporting program within five years, that would be great.
And if it took eight years, then it just took eight years.
That's all.
And you just don't find that kind of attitude or the ability to do that in other areas or in other institutions.
And so in any event, interestingly, shortly after that,
Very sure, within six months of that conversation I had with Mr. Benson, things started to break for us.

And again, it was because we'd had teased money to go out and do a few things, and I could go to the RAND program people in NSF, and to the HUD people, it was Housing and Urban Development at that time, and tell them what we had done.
We had a trash record.
I had faculty identified that had expertise, you see.
We had gone out and
and worked with a few of the cities, and I'd say, yeah, I know Marvin Townsend, the city manager at Fox, Christine, and other guys, you know, and police chiefs, and things like that.
And so, and again, that was all because of T's money.
And coupled with Mr. Benson's tremendously important...
understanding of what it takes to promote and develop these things.
And so within six months after that conversation, I think we had a backlog of something like $750,000 worth of research.
We had started, we had gotten into the Urban Observatory Program,
